ud3.9:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud3.9:1.3: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from almsround, several mendicants sat together in the pavilion and this discussion came up among them:
ud3.9:2.2: elephant-craft is the best of crafts.
ud3.9:2.3: Others said that the best craft is
ud3.9:2.25: At that point the conversation among those mendicants was left unfinished.
ud3.9:3.1: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall. He sat down on the seat spread out,
ud3.9:3.3: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
ud3.9:4.1: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about when the Buddha arrived. The Buddha said,
ud3.9:6.1: “Mendicants, it is not appropriate for you gentlemen who have gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness to talk about such things.
ud3.9:6.2: When you’re sitting together you should do one of two things:
ud3.9:6.3: discuss the teachings or keep noble silence.”
ud3.9:7.1: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud3.9:8.1: “Living without a craft, light, desiring the good,
ud3.9:8.3: a migrant with no shelter, unselfish, with no need for hope,
ud3.9:8.4: having given up conceit, wandering alone: that is a mendicant.”
